classes.name: PerfCounter
classes.documentation:
This class is used to track a performance counter which is number based.
The user has access to many properties which give statistics of different nature

The implementer can track two kinds of Performance Counter: time and count
For time you can optionally call fetchNewFrame() to notify the start of a new frame to monitor, then call beginMonitoring() to start and endMonitoring() to record the lapsed time. endMonitoring takes a newFrame parameter for you to specify if the monitored time should be set for a new frame or accumulated to the current frame being monitored.
For count you first have to call fetchNewFrame() to notify the start of a new frame to monitor, then call addCount() how many time required to increment the count value you monitor.

functions.name: fetchNewFrame
functions.documentation:
Call this method to start monitoring a new frame.
This scenario is typically used when you accumulate monitoring time many times for a single frame, you call this method at the start of the frame, then beginMonitoring to start recording and endMonitoring(false) to accumulated the recorded time to the PerfCounter or addCount() to accumulate a monitored count.

functionBody.documentation:
Call this method to start monitoring a new frame.
This scenario is typically used when you accumulate monitoring time many times for a single frame, you call this method at the start of the frame, then beginMonitoring to start recording and endMonitoring(false) to accumulated the recorded time to the PerfCounter or addCount() to accumulate a monitored count.

functions.name: addCount
functions.documentation: Call this method to monitor a count of something (e.g. mesh drawn in viewport count)

parameters.name: newCount
parameters.documentation: the count value to add to the monitored count

parameters.name: fetchResult
parameters.documentation: true when it's the last time in the frame you add to the counter and you wish to update the statistics properties (min/max/average), false if you only want to update statistics.

functionBody.documentation: Call this method to monitor a count of something (e.g. mesh drawn in viewport count)

functions.name: beginMonitoring
functions.documentation: Start monitoring this performance counter

functionBody.documentation: Start monitoring this performance counter

functions.name: endMonitoring
functions.documentation: Compute the time lapsed since the previous beginMonitoring() call.

parameters.name: newFrame
parameters.documentation: true by default to fetch the result and monitor a new frame, if false the time monitored will be added to the current frame counter

functionBody.documentation: Compute the time lapsed since the previous beginMonitoring() call.

properties.documentation: Returns the average value since the performance counter is running

properties.name: lastSecAverage
properties.documentation: Returns the average value of the last second the counter was monitored

properties.name: current
properties.documentation: Returns the current value

classes.name: ColorGradingTexture
classes.documentation:
This represents a color grading texture. This acts as a lookup table LUT, useful during post process
It can help converting any input color in a desired output one. This can then be used to create effects
from sepia, black and white to sixties or futuristic rendering...

The only supported format is currently 3dl.
More information on LUT: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3D_lookup_table/

parameters.documentation: The location of the color gradind data (currently only supporting 3dl)

Returns the texture matrix used in most of the material.
This is not used in color grading but keep for troubleshooting purpose (easily swap diffuse by colorgrading to look in).

classes.name: HDRCubeTexture

The only supported format is currently panorama picture stored in RGBE format.
Example of such files can be found on HDRLib: http://hdrlib.com/

functions.name: bindTextureForRect
functions.documentation:
Bind the texture to the rendering engine to render in the zone of a given rectangle.
Use this method when you want to render into the texture map with a clipspace set to the location and size of the given rect.
Don't forget to call unbindTexture when you're done rendering

parameters.name: rect
parameters.documentation: the zone to render to

parameters.name: clear
parameters.documentation: true to clear the portion's color/depth data

functionBody.documentation:
Bind the texture to the rendering engine to render in the zone of a given rectangle.
Use this method when you want to render into the texture map with a clipspace set to the location and size of the given rect.
Don't forget to call unbindTexture when you're done rendering

functions.name: bindTextureForPosSize
functions.documentation:
Bind the texture to the rendering engine to render in the zone of the given size at the given position.
Use this method when you want to render into the texture map with a clipspace set to the location and size of the given rect.
Don't forget to call unbindTexture when you're done rendering
functions.type: (pos: Vector2, size: Size, clear: boolean) => void

parameters.name: pos
parameters.documentation: the position into the texture

parameters.name: size
parameters.documentation: the portion to fit the clip space to

parameters.name: clear
parameters.documentation: true to clear the portion's color/depth data

functionBody.documentation:
Bind the texture to the rendering engine to render in the zone of the given size at the given position.
Use this method when you want to render into the texture map with a clipspace set to the location and size of the given rect.
Don't forget to call unbindTexture when you're done rendering

functions.name: unbindTexture
functions.documentation:
Unbind the texture map from the rendering engine.
Call this method when you're done rendering. A previous call to bindTextureForRect has to be made.

parameters.name: dumpForDebug
parameters.documentation: if set to true the content of the texture map will be dumped to a picture file that will be sent to the internet browser.

functionBody.documentation:
Unbind the texture map from the rendering engine.
Call this method when you're done rendering. A previous call to bindTextureForRect has to be made.

classes.name: PMREMGenerator
classes.documentation:
Helper class to PreProcess a cubemap in order to generate mipmap according to the level of blur
required by the glossinees of a material.

This only supports the cosine drop power as well as Warp fixup generation method.

This is using the process from CubeMapGen described here:
https://seblagarde.wordpress.com/2012/06/10/amd-cubemapgen-for-physically-based-rendering/

parameters.name: input
parameters.documentation: The different faces data from the original cubemap in the order X+ X- Y+ Y- Z+ Z-

parameters.name: inputSize
parameters.documentation: The size of the cubemap faces

parameters.name: outputSize
parameters.documentation: The size of the output cubemap faces

parameters.name: maxNumMipLevels
parameters.documentation: The max number of mip map to generate (0 means all)

parameters.name: numChannels
parameters.documentation: The number of channels stored in the cubemap (3 for RBGE for instance)

parameters.name: isFloat
parameters.documentation: Specifies if the input texture is in float or int (hdr is usually in float)

parameters.name: specularPower
parameters.documentation: The max specular level of the desired cubemap

parameters.name: cosinePowerDropPerMip
parameters.documentation: The amount of drop the specular power will follow on each mip

parameters.name: excludeBase
parameters.documentation: Specifies wether to process the level 0 (original level) or not

parameters.name: fixup
parameters.documentation: Specifies wether to apply the edge fixup algorythm or not

constructors.documentation: Constructor of the generator.

functions.name: filterCubeMap
functions.documentation:
Launches the filter process and return the result.

@return the filter cubemap in the form mip0 [faces1..6] .. mipN [faces1..6]
